newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan to lift freeze on grant-in-aid to China. [CORRECTED 4:24 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Japan to lift freeze on grant-in-aid to China. [CORRECTED 4:24 GMT]

text.p: Japan will end a freeze on grant-in-aid to China that was imposed in August 1995 to protest against China's nuclear tests, Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda said on Friday.

Ikeda, who travels to China on Saturday for a two-day visit, said he will sign documents in Beijing on Saturday for a grant of 1.7 billion yen ($13.8 million) for a medical project in Nanjing, ending the freeze on grant-in-aid.
Ikeda told a news conference that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's cabinet had approved the resumption of grant-in-aid.

Japan froze the grants, worth about seven billion yen ($56.9 million) per year, in August 1995 as a mainly symbolic protest against China's nuclear testing, saying China had violated a moratorium on those tests.
However, the Japanese government did not touch the bulk of its aid programme to China, about 580 billion yen ($4.71 billion) in yen loans in the 1996-1998 period.
In September 1996 (Corrects from 1995), China signed the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) at the United Nations and imposed a moratorium on future nuclear testing.
